subject: Re: [junit] Re: Swingui TestRunner
msgSnippet: Hmm- jumping to the offending line of code sounds valuable to me - didn t know it could be done! Is this the default behaviour? I m intriqued - once I get
messageBody:
Hmm- "jumping to the offending line of code" sounds valuable to me -
didn't know it could be done! Is this the default behaviour? I'm
intriqued - once I get some time I shall get back to junit to take a
look (sufficient to say that I'm one of only a few (3?) developers here
who use junit :-( ), so I spend a lot of time not using such useful
tools (groan!)

Toby

Mike Clark wrote:

>Vladimir Bossicard wrote:
>
>>My experience:
>>
>>- I started by using the Swing runner because I really liked the dynamic
>>reloading of the classes.
>>- I then discovered Cygwin and Ant and since then I totally dropped the Swing
>>runner (never used it once). The reason is simple: I run all the tests, all
>>the time, I don't have reloading problem, I can work with xml without modifying
>>the excluded.properties file.
>>
>
>You're obviously not addicted to a green bar! :-)
>
>Seriously, I find hitting the "Run" button (which I do very frequently)
>faster than firing up a new JVM for Ant. And when there is a failure, I
>double-click it in the Swing UI to jump right to the offending line of code.
>
>But that's just me...
>
>Mike
>
>
>
